text: But I think fundamentally this is the sort of thing that we actually work on So I'm going to talk to you about this idea that we are all a kind of collective intelligence In fact, I'm going to try to show you and again hard in 25 minutes, but I'll at least show you a few examples why I think really the world consists of intelligence all the way down, okay Not just brainy mammals and birds and things like that, but all the way down The implications of that, amazingly enough, are that we can reach all kinds of interesting new biomedicine if we understand how intelligence is implemented in our bodies And so that gives all kinds of opportunities There are always in the discussion of ethics, I'm sure somebody will be interested in the risks
content_summary: The speaker discusses the concept of collective intelligence, suggesting that it permeates all levels of biological life, not just 'brainy' mammals and birds. They propose that understanding how this intelligence is implemented in our bodies could lead to significant advancements in biomedicine, while also acknowledging the ethical considerations and potential risks.
